header.title: API to MCP Converter

seo.whatIsTitle: What is an API to MCP Server Converter?
seo.whatIsContent1: An API to MCP (Model Context Protocol) Converter transforms OpenAPI and Swagger specifications into fully functional MCP server implementations. The conversion automates server-side code generation, dramatically reducing development time.
seo.whatIsContent2: Our free online converter supports the official Model Context Protocol SDKs across multiple languages so you can generate servers in the language and runtime you prefer.
seo.howToTitle: How to Convert OpenAPI to MCP Server
seo.step1Content: Drag and drop or select your OpenAPI/Swagger JSON or YAML file
seo.step2Content: Choose which API endpoints you want to include in your MCP server
seo.step3Content: Choose the target MCP SDK (e.g. Python, TypeScript/Node.js, Go, Rust, Java, Kotlin, C#, PHP, Ruby, Swift)
seo.step4Content: Get your production-ready MCP server as a .zip bundle
seo.whyTitle: Why Use Our API to MCP Converter?
seo.feature1Content: Convert complex API specifications to MCP servers in seconds, not hours. Our optimized engine processes large specifications instantly.
seo.feature2Content: Generated code follows best practices and includes proper error handling, making it ready for immediate deployment.
seo.feature3Content: Your API specifications never leave your browser. All processing happens locally, ensuring complete privacy and security.
seo.feature4Content: No registration, no credit card, no limits. Convert unlimited API specifications to MCP servers for free.

whatIsMcp.title: What is Model Context Protocol (MCP)?
whatIsMcp.intro: Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a revolutionary open standard that enables seamless integration between AI applications and data sources. Developed to solve the fragmentation problem in AI tooling, MCP provides a universal way for AI models to interact with various data sources and services.
whatIsMcp.whyMattersPara1: Before MCP, developers had to build custom integrations for each AI application and data source combination. This created a complex web of point-to-point connections that were difficult to maintain and scale.
whatIsMcp.universalProtocolDesc: A single standard for AI-to-data connections
whatIsMcp.openSourceDesc: Community-driven with official SDKs in multiple languages
whatIsMcp.howWorksPara: MCP operates through a client-server architecture:
whatIsMcp.mcpServersDesc: expose data sources and capabilities through a standardized protocol
whatIsMcp.mcpClientsDesc: (AI applications) connect to these servers to access data
whatIsMcp.toolsResourcesDesc: are exposed through MCP's uniform interface
whatIsMcp.convertingPara: Our free online converter transforms existing OpenAPI/Swagger specifications into MCP servers automatically. This means you can:
whatIsMcp.convertingBenefit1: Expose existing REST APIs as MCP servers
whatIsMcp.convertingBenefit2: Enable AI applications to discover and use your APIs
whatIsMcp.convertingBenefit3: Generate production-ready code in your preferred language
whatIsMcp.convertingBenefit4: Support for Python, TypeScript, Go, Rust, Java, Kotlin, C#, PHP, Ruby, and Swift
whatIsMcp.gettingStartedPara: Converting your API to MCP is simple:
whatIsMcp.step2: Select the endpoints you want to expose

bestPractices.title: OpenAPI Best Practices for MCP Conversion
bestPractices.intro: To get the best results when converting your OpenAPI specification to an MCP server, follow these industry best practices for API design and documentation.
bestPractices.namingPara: Use meaningful, self-explanatory names for your endpoints, parameters, and schemas:
bestPractices.namingParametersDesc: Name parameters descriptively (e.g., userId instead of id)
bestPractices.namingSchemasDesc: Use PascalCase for schema names (e.g., UserProfile, ProductDetails)
bestPractices.descriptionsPara: Every element in your OpenAPI spec should have a clear description:
bestPractices.descriptionsApi: API-level description explaining the overall purpose
bestPractices.descriptionsResponses: Response descriptions detailing what each status code means
bestPractices.dataTypesPara: Use appropriate OpenAPI data types and formats:
bestPractices.dataTypesString: string with formats like date-time, email, uri
bestPractices.dataTypesInteger: integer with int32 or int64 format
bestPractices.dataTypesNumber: number with float or double format
bestPractices.dataTypesEnum: Use enum for restricted value sets
bestPractices.errorHandlingStatus: Document all HTTP status codes your API returns
bestPractices.errorHandlingMessages: Provide clear error messages in descriptions
